ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more about a wide variety of different cultural impacts. For example, indigenous culture, witches in reference to woman's rights, and fake news. My Spanish speaking abilities did not improve at all.
I learned a significant amount about art, culture, and the environment. Also, I was able to apply Spanish to many interesting projects and conversations.
A lot about interpreting art and movies etc in spanish
I really developed my Spanish speaking abilities as well as my writing abilities which I felt like were the skills I needed to work on the most
How to speak more fluently in Spanish, how to string sentences together
Deeper understanding of Latin American and indigenous history, social and political discussions, and improved speaking/writing
My command in Spanish speaking improved greatly
Spanish speaking skills and knowledge of indigenous cultures, climate change, and various Hispanic artists.
I learned more about Spanish culture and how to talk about global issues in Spanish. Our class discussed gender disparities, motherhood, and fake news as they are displayed in media and art today.
I developed my writing, speaking, and general understanding of spanish culture in this class.
Cultural analysis while using Spanish language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content was somewhat interesting and easy to talk about in a class discussion. The workload and grading was fair. This course however did not improve my Spanish at all. I understand the goal of the course was to practice speaking and developing my speaking ability, but I really would have liked to learn more tenses and sentence structure because some of the thigs we covered was boring and not really relevant to modern life.
More directed ways of grammar learning would be helpful -- namely new vocabulary (and quizzes on it). I felt that we were not held accountable to learning/using grammar properly.
I think the only thing would be less jam boards but those will definitely go away with covid
Discussion seminar format was wonderful, and my voice always felt heard. Profesora Glenski always gave thorough and helpful feedback.
Great teacher

I liked how this course encouraged a lot of participation but I wish that we had a bit more focus on grammar. It was difficult to improve my actual Spanish speaking...I could only understand those with more sophisticated speech.

A strength of this course is the discussion style of the class that facilitates speaking and interacting with the class and your fellow classmates, along with the way in which ideas are introduced with plays, slides, art, and movies. The weaknesses are the topics covered which can get repetitive and somewhat boring.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want to develop your speaking skills while reading somewhat interesting texts go ahead! Mostly just take it if you need the language credit its a very fair and simple class.
I would recommend it; Professor Glenski was excellent.

Yes I would because you learn a lot and its a different kind of Spanish class than most people have probably taken before. There is a large focus on culture and very little focus on grammar and vocab which is really interesting

You get out of this course what you put into it. If you google translate the whole time, you wont learn much. If you pay attention to the vocab and grammar structures used in the texts youre analyzing and make the effort, youll get even more out of it than if the prof was making you do grammar worksheets.
Yes, it is a fascinating course led by wonderful professors, and you will so much learn from your peers.
Yes I would
I would. This is a required course if one wants to fulfill their language requirements and it is a nice break from the workload of L3 Spanish.
I would recommend this course for a language credit as it is not too difficult and the class is engaging and you get exposed to many primary sources of spanish culture.
Yes, the topics are so interesting.
